user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int irq_notify_fd
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the code fragment calls metal_log (a logging macro) with a format string and __func__. Rule 21.17 concerns use of <string.h> functions (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.) that can access beyond object bounds. This fragment does not call any of those functions and simply passes a pointer to the static function-name string (__func__) to a printf‑style handler. Unless the underlying log_handler implementation itself uses a <string.h> function incorrectly (not visible here), there is no direct violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
